restaurant_dinner_reservation.name: Making a Dinner Reservation (Updated)
restaurant_dinner_reservation.description: Practice making a dinner reservation at a restaurant, ordering food, and handling the bill. - Updated for testing
restaurant_dinner_reservation.setting: An upscale restaurant in the city center

phases.name: Making the Reservation
phases.description: Call or visit to make a dinner reservation
essential_phrases: I'd like to make a reservation
phases.cultural_notes: In many cultures, advance reservations are expected for dinner at upscale restaurants.
success_criteria: Provide party size and preferred time

phases.name: Arrival and Seating
phases.description: Arrive at the restaurant and get seated
essential_phrases: Would you prefer a table or booth?

phases.name: Ordering Food and Drinks
phases.description: Review menu and place your order
success_criteria: Ask at least one question about the menu

phases.name: Paying the Bill
phases.description: Review bill, tip appropriately, and complete payment
essential_phrases: Could we have the check, please?

cultural_context.tipping_culture: Standard tip is 15-20% for good service
cultural_context.dining_etiquette: Wait for everyone to be served before eating
cultural_context.payment_customs: Usually one person pays for the group

hotel_check_in.name: Hotel Check-in Process
hotel_check_in.description: Check into a hotel, handle room requests, and get local information.
hotel_check_in.setting: Hotel reception desk in a foreign country

phases.name: Hotel Check-in
phases.description: Provide reservation details and complete check-in process
essential_phrases: Could I see your ID please?
Your room is on the third floor

phases.name: Room Preferences and Requests
phases.description: Discuss room features and make special requests
essential_phrases: Is there a room with a view?
Could I request a non-smoking room?
success_criteria: Make at least one room preference request

phases.name: Getting Local Information
phases.description: Ask for directions and recommendations for local attractions
essential_phrases: What would you recommend for sightseeing?
Could you mark it on the map?
success_criteria: Get directions to at least one attraction

cultural_context.hospitality_customs: Hotel staff are usually very helpful with tourist information
cultural_context.tipping_culture: Small tips for helpful service are appreciated
cultural_context.local_etiquette: Always be polite and patient with language barriers

clothing_shopping.name: Clothes Shopping Experience
clothing_shopping.description: Shop for clothes, try on items, and make purchases.
clothing_shopping.setting: Clothing store in a shopping mall

phases.name: Browsing and Initial Inquiry
phases.description: Look around the store and ask for help
essential_phrases: Do you have this in blue?

phases.name: Trying on Clothes
phases.description: Use fitting room and get feedback on fit
essential_phrases: Do you have a larger size?

phases.name: Making the Purchase
phases.description: Decide on items and complete the purchase

cultural_context.shopping_etiquette: It's normal to try on clothes before buying
cultural_context.payment_methods: Most stores accept both cash and cards
cultural_context.return_policy: Keep receipts for returns or exchanges

phases.name: Introduction
phases.description: Initial greeting and context setting
essential_phrases: I'd like to make a reservation

phases.name: Booking Details
phases.description: Providing reservation details

phases.name: Confirmation
phases.description: Confirming the reservation

ebe8ce54-5da9-4f0a-af91-fe350fd4695b.name: Test CRUD Scenario
ebe8ce54-5da9-4f0a-af91-fe350fd4695b.description: A test scenario for CRUD operations

phases.name: Meeting Start
phases.description: Opening the meeting

c67d69a3-d71d-4144-8a57-d389c0cc168d.name: Valid Test Scenario
c67d69a3-d71d-4144-8a57-d389c0cc168d.description: A valid test scenario with all required fields

phases.name: Valid Phase
phases.description: A valid phase

phases.name: Lesson Introduction
phases.description: Introduction to the lesson

integrity_test_scenario.name: Data Integrity Test Scenario
integrity_test_scenario.description: A complex scenario to test data integrity across persistence

phases.name: Check-in Process
phases.description: Patient check-in and registration
phases.cultural_notes: Healthcare system procedures

phases.name: Medical Consultation
phases.description: Discussion with healthcare provider
essential_phrases: How long has this been going on?
phases.cultural_notes: Doctor-patient communication

validation_test_valid.name: Valid Validation Test
validation_test_valid.description: A valid scenario for validation testing

phases.name: Valid Phase
phases.description: A valid phase

business_meeting_first_time.name: First Business Meeting with International Partners
business_meeting_first_time.description: Practice conducting your first business meeting with international colleagues, including introductions, small talk, discussing the agenda, and closing professionally.
business_meeting_first_time.setting: Modern conference room in an international company office

phases.name: Professional Introductions
phases.description: Exchange introductions and business cards
essential_phrases: What's your role in the company?
phases.cultural_notes: In international business, firm handshakes and eye contact show professionalism. Business cards should be presented and received with both hands in many Asian cultures.

phases.name: Small Talk and Rapport Building
phases.description: Build professional rapport through appropriate small talk
essential_phrases: Have you had time to see the city?
Is everything comfortable with your accommodation?
The weather has been nice lately
learning_objectives: Engage in appropriate business small talk
phases.cultural_notes: Small talk before business is important in most cultures. Keep topics neutral (weather, travel) and avoid politics or religion.
success_criteria: Engage in at least 2 minutes of small talk
Ask courteous questions about their comfort

phases.name: Agenda Discussion
phases.description: Review agenda and participate in business discussions
essential_phrases: What are your thoughts on this proposal?
Should we move to the next item?
Let me make a note of that
phases.cultural_notes: In Western business culture, meetings are usually structured with a clear agenda. Everyone is expected to contribute. In some cultures, junior members speak less.
success_criteria: Contribute to at least one discussion point

phases.name: Professional Closing
phases.description: Summarize decisions and agree on next steps
essential_phrases: Let me summarize our key decisions
When should we schedule our follow-up?
Thank you for your time today
I'll send you the meeting notes
phases.cultural_notes: Always end with clear next steps and deadlines. Following up with written notes is professional practice in most business cultures.

cultural_context.meeting_etiquette: Arrive on time, silence phones, take notes, participate actively
cultural_context.communication_style: Direct but polite communication is valued in international business
cultural_context.hierarchical_awareness: Be aware that some cultures have stronger hierarchy than others

job_interview_professional.name: Professional Job Interview
job_interview_professional.description: Practice interviewing for a professional position, including self-introduction, discussing experience, answering competency questions, and asking about the role.
job_interview_professional.setting: Company interview room or virtual video call

phases.name: Introduction and Icebreaker
phases.description: Professional self-introduction and initial questions
essential_phrases: Thank you for inviting me to interview
I have... years of experience in...
What interests you about this role?
phases.cultural_notes: First impressions matter greatly. Dress professionally, arrive 10 minutes early, and maintain confident body language. In video interviews, ensure good lighting and quiet background.
success_criteria: Express genuine interest in the role

phases.name: Experience Discussion
phases.description: Discuss work history and achievements
essential_phrases: In my previous role, I was responsible for...
One of my key achievements was...
I successfully led a project to...
I worked with a team to...
phases.cultural_notes: Use the STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result) to structure answers. Be specific with examples and quantify achievements when possible.
success_criteria: Demonstrate skills matching the job requirements

phases.name: Competency Questions
phases.description: Answer behavioral and situational questions
essential_phrases: When faced with that situation, I...
phases.cultural_notes: Be honest but positive about weaknesses. Show how you're improving. Western culture values taking initiative and speaking up about accomplishments.

phases.name: Questions and Closing
phases.description: Ask about role and understand next steps
essential_phrases: What would you expect from me in the first 90 days?
Can you tell me about the team I'd be working with?
What are the opportunities for growth?
What are the next steps in the process?
When can I expect to hear back?
learning_objectives: Ask intelligent questions about the role
phases.cultural_notes: Asking questions shows genuine interest. Avoid asking about salary in first interview unless they bring it up. Always thank them for their time.
success_criteria: Understand next steps in hiring process

cultural_context.interview_preparation: Research the company beforehand, prepare questions, bring copies of resume
cultural_context.appropriate_attire: Business professional or business casual depending on company culture
cultural_context.follow_up: Send thank-you email within 24 hours reiterating interest

making_friends_social_event.name: Making New Friends at a Social Event
making_friends_social_event.description: Practice meeting someone new at a social gathering, finding common interests, making plans to meet again, and exchanging contact information.
making_friends_social_event.setting: Casual social event like a party, community gathering, or hobby meetup

phases.name: Breaking the Ice
phases.description: Initiate friendly conversation
essential_phrases: Is this your first time here?
How do you know the host?
phases.cultural_notes: Smiling and open body language are universal signs of friendliness. In some cultures, physical proximity varies - be aware of personal space preferences.
success_criteria: Show genuine interest in the other person

phases.name: Finding Common Interests
phases.description: Discover shared hobbies and activities
essential_phrases: What do you like to do in your free time?
phases.cultural_notes: Finding common ground builds friendship. Be genuinely curious about their interests even if different from yours. Active listening shows respect.

phases.name: Making Plans
phases.description: Suggest activity and arrange to meet again
essential_phrases: Would you like to grab coffee?
phases.cultural_notes: Making specific plans shows genuine interest. In some cultures, invitations are more spontaneous; in others, advanced planning is preferred.

phases.name: Exchanging Contact Information
phases.description: Exchange contact details and conclude warmly
phases.cultural_notes: In digital age, social media connections are common. Choose method both are comfortable with. Follow up within a day or two to maintain momentum.
success_criteria: Agree on how to follow up

cultural_context.friendship_building: Friendships take time to develop. Multiple interactions build trust and connection
cultural_context.social_norms: Be yourself while being respectful of cultural differences in friendship customs
cultural_context.follow_through: Following up after initial meeting is crucial. Don't wait too long to reconnect

attending_cultural_festival.name: Attending a Cultural Festival
attending_cultural_festival.description: Experience a local cultural festival, learning about traditions, trying foods, and engaging with cultural activities while practicing language skills.
attending_cultural_festival.setting: Community cultural festival with food stalls, performances, and activities

phases.name: Festival Overview
phases.description: Learn about festival significance and plan
essential_phrases: Can you tell me about the traditions?
phases.cultural_notes: Cultural festivals celebrate heritage and community. Showing genuine interest and respect is appreciated. Ask questions to learn more.
success_criteria: Ask at least 3 questions about traditions

phases.name: Trying Traditional Foods
phases.description: Sample traditional dishes and learn about cuisine
phases.cultural_notes: Food is central to cultural identity. Be adventurous but know your limits. Complimenting food shows appreciation for culture.

phases.name: Participating in Activities
phases.description: Join traditional activities or watch performances
phases.cultural_notes: Participation is usually welcomed if done respectfully. Ask before taking photos, especially of people in traditional dress.
success_criteria: Participate in or observe at least 1 activity

phases.name: Reflection and Gratitude
phases.description: Share experience and express appreciation
essential_phrases: Thank you for sharing your culture
phases.cultural_notes: Expressing genuine appreciation for cultural sharing builds bridges. Many people love sharing their heritage with interested visitors.

cultural_context.respectful_participation: Show respect through genuine interest, appropriate dress, and following local customs
cultural_context.photography_etiquette: Always ask before photographing people or sacred objects
cultural_context.cultural_exchange: Festivals are opportunities for cultural exchange and building understanding

doctor_visit_consultation.name: Doctor's Visit for Health Consultation
doctor_visit_consultation.description: Visit a doctor for a health concern, describing symptoms, understanding diagnosis, and discussing treatment options.

phases.name: Check-in and Symptoms
phases.description: Describe reason for visit and symptoms
phases.cultural_notes: Be specific about symptoms - doctors need details. In Western medicine, directness about bodily functions is professional, not embarrassing.

phases.name: Examination and Questions
phases.description: Undergo examination and answer questions
phases.cultural_notes: Doctors may ask personal questions necessary for diagnosis. Patient privacy is protected by law in most countries.

phases.name: Diagnosis and Explanation
phases.description: Understand diagnosis and ask questions
phases.cultural_notes: Don't hesitate to ask doctor to explain in simpler terms. Understanding your diagnosis is your right as a patient.

phases.name: Treatment and Follow-up
phases.description: Discuss treatment plan and next steps
essential_phrases: How do I take this medication?
phases.cultural_notes: Always ask about medication instructions, side effects, and what to do if symptoms worsen. Keep a list of your medications.

cultural_context.patient_rights: Patients have right to understand diagnosis, ask questions, and participate in treatment decisions
cultural_context.privacy: Medical information is confidential. Doctors cannot share without permission
cultural_context.second_opinions: Seeking second opinion for serious diagnosis is acceptable and common

medical_emergency_response.name: Responding to Medical Emergency
medical_emergency_response.description: Handle a medical emergency situation, calling for help, providing information to emergency services, and communicating urgently.

phases.name: Making Emergency Call
phases.description: Call emergency services and state emergency
phases.cultural_notes: Emergency number varies by country (911 in US/Canada, 999 in UK, 112 in EU). Staying calm helps dispatcher help you faster.

phases.name: Providing Location
phases.description: Give precise location information
phases.cultural_notes: Know your address or be able to identify landmarks. Dispatchers need precise location to send help. If unsure, describe surroundings.
success_criteria: Provide exact address or clear location

phases.name: Describing Victim's Condition
phases.description: Describe person's symptoms and status
phases.cultural_notes: Dispatchers are trained to extract crucial information. Answer their questions directly. They may guide you through first aid steps.

phases.name: Following Instructions
phases.description: Follow dispatcher's first aid instructions
phases.cultural_notes: Stay on the line until help arrives. Dispatchers can guide life-saving procedures. Don't hang up unless told to.
success_criteria: Stay on line until help arrives

cultural_context.emergency_numbers: Know local emergency number. In many countries you can call emergency services even without phone credit
cultural_context.dispatcher_role: Emergency dispatchers are trained to help. Trust their guidance and stay calm
cultural_context.staying_safe: Your safety is also important. Don't put yourself in danger while helping others

pharmacy_visit.name: At the Pharmacy
pharmacy_visit.description: Visit a pharmacy to pick up prescription medication, ask about over-the-counter options, and understand usage instructions.

phases.name: Picking Up Prescription
phases.description: Provide information and collect prescription
essential_phrases: I'm here to pick up a prescription
phases.cultural_notes: Pharmacies verify identity for safety. Have ID ready. Insurance cards may be needed. Some prescriptions require signatures.

phases.name: Understanding Instructions
phases.description: Learn how to take medication properly
essential_phrases: Should I take it with food?
phases.cultural_notes: Always ask questions about medication. Pharmacists are experts and happy to explain. Follow instructions exactly as given.
success_criteria: Understand when and how to take medication

phases.name: Over-the-Counter Options
phases.description: Ask about non-prescription remedies
phases.cultural_notes: Generic medications are same quality as brand names but cheaper. Pharmacists can recommend options for common ailments.

phases.name: Payment and Final Questions
phases.description: Complete purchase and ask remaining questions
essential_phrases: Can I return it if it doesn't work?
phases.cultural_notes: Keep receipts for insurance reimbursement or returns. Copays vary by insurance. Some medications cannot be returned once purchased.

cultural_context.pharmacist_expertise: Pharmacists are medication experts. They can answer questions and catch potential problems
cultural_context.privacy: Pharmacies have privacy laws. Your medication information is confidential
cultural_context.medication_adherence: Taking medications as prescribed is crucial for effectiveness and safety

post_office_visit.name: At the Post Office
post_office_visit.description: Visit post office to send a package, buy stamps, and handle various postal services.

phases.name: Sending a Package
phases.description: Prepare and send a package
essential_phrases: I'd like to send this package
phases.cultural_notes: Post offices ask about contents for safety and customs. Be honest. Declaring items incorrectly can cause delays or legal issues.

phases.name: Choosing Shipping Options
phases.description: Compare speeds and costs
phases.cultural_notes: Faster shipping costs more. Insurance protects valuable items. Signature confirmation ensures delivery to person, not just door.

phases.name: Buying Stamps
phases.description: Purchase stamps and understand usage
essential_phrases: How many stamps do I need?
Can I get a book of stamps?
phases.cultural_notes: 'Forever stamps' in US never expire and are always valid for first-class mail regardless of price increases. Good investment.

phases.name: Payment and Receipt
phases.description: Complete payment and get documentation
phases.cultural_notes: Keep tracking numbers and receipts. They're proof of mailing and needed for claims if package is lost. Most post offices accept cards now.

cultural_context.postal_services: Post offices offer many services beyond mailing: passports, money orders, PO boxes
cultural_context.customs_forms: International packages require customs forms declaring contents and value
cultural_context.proof_of_mailing: Always get receipt with tracking for important items. It's your proof of sending

sports_discussion.name: Discussing Sports and Games
sports_discussion.description: Have a casual conversation about sports, favorite teams, recent games, and sports-related activities.
sports_discussion.setting: Casual setting like bar, party, or workplace break room

phases.name: Talking About Favorite Sports
phases.description: Discuss sports preferences and interests
phases.cultural_notes: Sports are common social topics. Being a fan creates connections. Different regions have different popular sports (football/soccer, American football, basketball, baseball, cricket, etc.).

phases.name: Discussing Recent Games
phases.description: Talk about recent matches and performances
essential_phrases: Did you see the game last night?
phases.cultural_notes: Sports discussions can be passionate but friendly. Regional and national pride often involved. Be respectful of rival team fans.
success_criteria: Discuss at least one recent game

phases.name: Predictions and Opinions
phases.description: Share predictions and debate sports topics
essential_phrases: Who do you think will win?
phases.cultural_notes: Sports predictions and debates are fun social activities. Friendly disagreement is normal. Avoid betting discussions unless others bring it up.

phases.name: Personal Sports Experience
phases.description: Share personal sports participation
essential_phrases: I'm trying to get back into...
I just watch, I don't play
phases.cultural_notes: Many people enjoy sports recreationally. Youth sports are important in many cultures. Playing sports shows activity and health consciousness.

learning_outcomes: Build social connections through shared interests

cultural_context.sports_culture: Sports are major social topics globally. Understanding local favorites helps integration
cultural_context.team_loyalty: Team loyalty is often regional or family-based and can be lifelong
cultural_context.sportsmanship: Good sportsmanship values winning graciously and losing with dignity

banking_account_services.name: Banking and Financial Services
banking_account_services.description: Visit a bank to open an account, discuss financial products, understand banking services, and handle transactions.
banking_account_services.setting: Bank branch or online banking consultation

phases.name: Opening an Account
phases.description: Learn about account types and open a new account
essential_phrases: I'd like to open an account
What types of accounts do you offer?
Is there a minimum balance required?
I'd like to open a checking account
phases.cultural_notes: Banks in many countries require government-issued ID and proof of address. Opening an account may require an initial deposit. Ask about all fees upfront - monthly maintenance, overdraft, ATM fees. Compare different account types before deciding.
success_criteria: Ask about at least 2 account types

phases.name: Banking Services Overview
phases.description: Learn about available banking services and products
essential_phrases: Can I get a debit card?
How do I set up direct deposit?
phases.cultural_notes: Online and mobile banking are standard in most countries. Set up online banking immediately - it's more convenient than visiting branches. Direct deposit is preferred by most employers. Keep your PIN secret and change it regularly.
success_criteria: Know how to get debit/credit cards
Ask about fees for various services

phases.name: Making a Transaction
phases.description: Perform common banking transactions
essential_phrases: I'd like to deposit this check
I need to withdraw some cash
Can I transfer money to another account?
How long will this transaction take?
phases.cultural_notes: Always get receipts for transactions. Checks take 1-5 business days to clear. Wire transfers are usually same-day but have fees. ATMs are convenient but may charge fees if not from your bank. Keep transaction records for taxes.

phases.name: Questions and Security
phases.description: Ask about security features and get contact information
essential_phrases: What if I see fraudulent charges?
How do I contact customer service?
phases.cultural_notes: Banks have fraud protection, but report suspicious activity immediately. Use strong passwords and enable two-factor authentication. Never share passwords or PINs. Customer service is available 24/7 for most banks. Register your phone for alerts about unusual activity.

cultural_context.banking_hours: Most banks open weekdays 9 AM - 5 PM, some Saturday mornings
cultural_context.documentation: Bring passport/ID and proof of address for new accounts
cultural_context.fees: Ask about ALL fees - monthly maintenance, ATM, overdraft, wire transfer
cultural_context.online_banking: Essential for modern banking; set up immediately
cultural_context.security: Banks never ask for passwords by email or phone

dental_checkup_appointment.name: Dental Check-up and Treatment
dental_checkup_appointment.description: Schedule and attend a dental appointment, describe dental issues, understand treatment options, and learn proper dental care.

phases.name: Scheduling Appointment
phases.description: Call dentist office and schedule appointment
essential_phrases: I'd like to schedule a dental appointment
Is this an emergency or routine checkup?
phases.cultural_notes: Schedule checkups every 6 months for prevention. Emergency dental care available for severe pain or injury. Bring insurance card and ID to first appointment. New patient forms can often be filled out online before visit.

phases.name: Check-up Examination
phases.description: Undergo dental examination and describe problems
essential_phrases: I have pain in this tooth
My gums bleed when I brush
This tooth is sensitive to cold
I think I have a cavity
phases.cultural_notes: Be specific about pain location and type (sharp, dull, constant, occasional). Dental x-rays are safe and help find hidden problems. Tell dentist about fear or anxiety - they can help. Inform them of any medical conditions or medications.
success_criteria: Communicate pain or discomfort during exam

phases.name: Treatment Discussion
phases.description: Learn about necessary treatments and options
essential_phrases: How long will the procedure take?
learning_objectives: Ask about costs and insurance coverage
phases.cultural_notes: Dental work can be expensive. Ask for cost estimate before proceeding. Many dentists offer payment plans. Get second opinion for expensive treatments if unsure. Dental insurance often covers preventive care 100% but only 50-80% of major work.

phases.name: Dental Care Instructions
phases.description: Receive care instructions and prevention advice
essential_phrases: How should I care for my teeth?
phases.cultural_notes: Brush twice daily for 2 minutes, floss daily. Use fluoride toothpaste. Replace toothbrush every 3 months. Limit sugary foods and drinks. Regular checkups prevent expensive problems. Schedule next appointment before leaving.

cultural_context.regular_checkups: Every 6 months is standard for prevention
cultural_context.insurance: Dental usually separate from medical insurance
cultural_context.costs: Preventive care cheaper than treatment; get estimates upfront
cultural_context.emergency_care: Severe pain, bleeding, or injury requires immediate care

meeting_neighbors_community.name: Meeting Your New Neighbors
meeting_neighbors_community.description: Introduce yourself to neighbors, learn about the neighborhood, build community connections, and understand local customs.

phases.name: Introduction and Greeting
phases.description: Initiate friendly introduction as new neighbor
essential_phrases: How long have you lived here?
phases.cultural_notes: In many cultures, introducing yourself to neighbors is polite and expected. A friendly wave or 'hello' builds community. Some cultures are more private, others very social. Observe local norms. Small talk about weather or area is safe conversation starter.

phases.name: Learning About the Area
phases.description: Ask about neighborhood amenities and recommendations
essential_phrases: How do you like living here?
phases.cultural_notes: Neighbors are great sources of local knowledge. Ask about favorite spots, services to avoid, safety tips. Most people enjoy helping newcomers. Questions about area show genuine interest in community. This builds relationships and helps you settle in.
success_criteria: Ask at least 3 questions about area

phases.name: Discussing Common Interests
phases.description: Find common ground and shared interests
essential_phrases: What do you do for work?
phases.cultural_notes: Finding common ground builds friendships. Safe topics: kids, pets, hobbies, work (general). Avoid politics or religion initially. If they have kids/pets and you do too, that's instant connection. Show genuine interest in their responses.

phases.name: Exchanging Contacts
phases.description: Exchange contact information and express interest in staying connected
essential_phrases: Can I get your phone number?
Feel free to call if you need anything
Let me know if you need help
phases.cultural_notes: Exchanging numbers shows openness to friendship but doesn't obligate anyone. 'Let me know if you need anything' is polite offer in many cultures. Following through shows good neighborliness. A friendly relationship with neighbors improves quality of life and safety.

cultural_context.neighborliness: Varies by culture - some very social, others more private
cultural_context.boundaries: Friendly but respect privacy; don't be intrusive
cultural_context.community: Good neighbors enhance safety and quality of life
cultural_context.local_knowledge: Neighbors know best restaurants, services, safety tips

airport_navigation_departure.name: Navigating the Airport (Departure)
airport_navigation_departure.description: Navigate airport from check-in through security to boarding, handle travel documents, understand announcements, and deal with common situations.
airport_navigation_departure.setting: Airport from check-in to boarding gate

phases.name: Check-in and Baggage
phases.description: Check in for flight and check baggage
essential_phrases: I'd like to check in for my flight
Can I get a window seat?
Where do I check my luggage?
learning_objectives: Check in for international or domestic flight
phases.cultural_notes: Arrive 2-3 hours before international flights, 90 minutes for domestic. Have passport/ID and confirmation ready. Most airlines charge for checked bags. Carry-on must fit size restrictions. Liquids limited to 3.4oz containers in clear bag. Check airline's baggage policy online before arriving.
success_criteria: Successfully check in and get boarding pass
Understand seat assignment and gate number

phases.name: Security Screening
phases.description: Navigate airport security checkpoint
essential_phrases: Do I need to remove my shoes?
Should I take out my laptop?
Where do I put my belongings?
Am I allowed to bring this?
Can I keep my belt on?
phases.cultural_notes: Security procedures vary by country but generally similar. Remove shoes, belt, jacket. Take out laptop and liquids. Put items in bins. Walk through metal detector when told. Stay calm and follow instructions. Security officers are there for everyone's safety. Answer questions honestly and clearly.

phases.name: Finding Your Gate
phases.description: Navigate terminal and locate departure gate
essential_phrases: How do I get to concourse C?
phases.cultural_notes: Check departure monitors frequently - gates can change. Listen for announcements about your flight. Boarding usually starts 30-45 minutes before departure. Be at gate at least 30 minutes before boarding time. Airports have shops and restaurants but stay near your gate. Free WiFi usually available.
success_criteria: Arrive at gate with time to spare

phases.name: Boarding Process
phases.description: Board aircraft and find seat
essential_phrases: Can you help with my bag?
phases.cultural_notes: Boarding is by groups/zones - wait for your group to be called. Have boarding pass ready. Seat numbers on overhead bins help you find row. Put small bag under seat in front, larger in overhead bin. Be considerate of other passengers. Turn off phone or switch to airplane mode. Fasten seatbelt when seated.

cultural_context.timing: Arrive early; international flights require more time
cultural_context.security: Procedures strict but protect everyone; cooperate fully
cultural_context.documentation: Keep passport and boarding pass accessible always
cultural_context.flexibility: Flights can be delayed; stay informed and patient

car_rental_process.name: Renting a Car
car_rental_process.description: Rent a car for travel, understand rental agreement, discuss insurance options, and learn about vehicle operation and return procedures.
car_rental_process.setting: Car rental counter at airport or location

phases.name: Reservation and Pickup
phases.description: Confirm reservation and provide required documents
essential_phrases: I need a car for three days
Can I pay with a debit card?
phases.cultural_notes: Need valid driver's license (international license if from another country), credit card in your name, and minimum age (usually 21-25). Reservation guarantees vehicle type but not specific car. Early arrival helps ensure availability. Some companies don't accept debit cards or charge extra fees.

phases.name: Vehicle Selection and Features
phases.description: Choose vehicle and learn about its features
essential_phrases: What size car did I reserve?
Can I upgrade to a larger car?
How do I operate this feature?
phases.cultural_notes: In US/Canada, most cars are automatic. In Europe, manual is common. GPS helpful in unfamiliar areas but may cost extra. Full-to-full fuel policy is fairest - return with full tank. Unlimited mileage typical in US, limited in some countries. Inspect car before leaving lot.
success_criteria: Know how to operate basic controls

phases.name: Insurance and Agreement
phases.description: Discuss insurance coverage and sign rental contract
essential_phrases: My credit card includes rental insurance
phases.cultural_notes: Collision Damage Waiver (CDW) covers damage to rental car. Liability covers damage to other vehicles. Personal Accident Insurance covers injuries. Check if your credit card or personal auto insurance covers rentals before buying expensive coverage. Read agreement carefully - note mileage limits, fuel policy, return time. Ask about all fees.

phases.name: Vehicle Inspection and Return Info
phases.description: Inspect vehicle and understand return procedures
essential_phrases: Where do I return the car?
What time is it due back?
What if I return it late?
Where do I drop off the keys?
phases.cultural_notes: Walk around car with agent noting all scratches, dents, damage before leaving. Take photos as evidence. Know exact return location and time - late returns incur hourly fees. Return with full tank if that's policy, or pay inflated fuel charges. Most locations have after-hours drop-off. Get receipt showing condition when returned.
success_criteria: Understand fuel and late return policies

cultural_context.age_requirements: Usually 21-25 minimum, surcharges for young drivers
cultural_context.insurance: Coverage rules vary; check personal policy and credit card benefits
cultural_context.fuel_policy: Full-to-full most common; cheaper than prepaid options

grocery_store_shopping.name: Grocery Store Shopping
grocery_store_shopping.description: Navigate a grocery store, find items, ask for help, understand products, and complete checkout process.

phases.name: Finding Products
phases.description: Navigate store layout and locate items
essential_phrases: Where can I find the milk?
Which aisle is the bread in?
Can you help me find something?
learning_objectives: Ask employees for help finding items
phases.cultural_notes: Stores organized by sections: produce (fruits/vegetables), dairy (milk/cheese), meat, frozen foods, bakery. Aisles numbered with signs showing categories. Organic products usually have separate section or labels. Store employees wear name tags or uniforms. Don't hesitate to ask for help - they're there to assist.
success_criteria: Successfully locate at least 3 different sections
Ask employee for help when needed

phases.name: Reading Labels and Selecting
phases.description: Read product labels and make selections
phases.cultural_notes: Expiration dates: 'Best by' is quality recommendation, 'Use by' is safety. Price per unit (ounce/pound) helps compare different sizes. Generic/store brands usually cheaper than name brands with similar quality. Check for sales - yellow tags, shelf tags, or weekly ads. Organic products cost more. Read ingredients if you have allergies.

phases.name: Asking Staff for Help
phases.description: Request assistance from store employees
essential_phrases: Excuse me, can you help me?
Do you have any more of these?
Can you check in the back?
phases.cultural_notes: Store employees are resources - ask for help finding items, checking stock, or recommendations. If item is out of stock, they can check inventory or suggest substitutes. Managers can help with special requests or complaints. Be polite and patient - they help many customers daily.
success_criteria: Get question answered or problem solved

phases.name: Checkout and Payment
phases.description: Complete purchase at checkout
phases.cultural_notes: Most stores accept credit/debit cards, some cash only. Loyalty cards offer discounts and earn rewards - sign up is usually free. Some places charge for plastic bags; bring reusable bags to save money and environment. Coupons save money but check expiration dates. Always get receipt for returns or price verification.

cultural_context.store_layout: Similar organization in most countries; ask if lost
cultural_context.bagging: Some countries bag for you, others self-service
cultural_context.loyalty_cards: Free and provide discounts; worth signing up
cultural_context.organic_specialty: More expensive but growing in popularity

electronics_store_purchase.name: Buying Electronics
electronics_store_purchase.description: Purchase electronics, compare products, understand technical specifications, discuss warranties, and arrange delivery or setup.

phases.name: Product Inquiry
phases.description: Ask about products and compare options
essential_phrases: I'm looking for a new laptop
What's the difference between these models?
Can you show me the features?
How does this compare to that one?
phases.cultural_notes: Sales associates work on commission so may push expensive models. Know your needs and budget beforehand. Do research online before visiting store. Ask specific questions about features you need. Don't feel pressured to buy immediately - compare prices at different stores or online.
success_criteria: Get information about at least 2 products

phases.name: Technical Specifications
phases.description: Understand technical details and compatibility
essential_phrases: How much memory does this have?
How long does the battery last?
Is this compatible with my devices?
Does it have a USB-C port?
What operating system does it run?
phases.cultural_notes: Technical specs matter for performance. More RAM and faster processor = better performance. Storage (GB/TB) determines how much you can store. Battery life important for portability. Check compatibility with your existing devices. USB-C is newer standard. Operating system (Windows, Mac, Android, iOS) affects software availability.

phases.name: Warranty and Protection Plans
phases.description: Learn about warranties and decide on protection
essential_phrases: Should I buy the extended warranty?
phases.cultural_notes: Manufacturer warranty typically 1 year, covers defects not accidents. Extended warranties cost extra and may not be worth it - check credit card benefits first. Accident protection covers drops/spills but read fine print. Some warranties require registration. Keep receipt and warranty information. Electronics can be returned within 14-30 days at most stores if unopened.
success_criteria: Know how to use warranty if needed

phases.name: Purchase and Delivery
phases.description: Complete purchase and arrange delivery/setup
essential_phrases: Can I pick it up today?
Can I get this in writing?
phases.cultural_notes: Sales tax added at checkout (not included in displayed price in US). Large items can often be delivered for fee or free over certain amount. Some stores offer installation/setup services. Keep all packaging and receipts for potential returns. Return policies vary: typically 14-30 days, may require original packaging, some charge restocking fee.

cultural_context.research_first: Check reviews and prices online before visiting store
cultural_context.sales_tactics: Associates may push expensive items or warranties
cultural_context.return_policies: Vary by store; keep packaging and receipts
cultural_context.price_matching: Many stores match competitor prices if you ask

reporting_crime_police.name: Reporting a Crime to Police
reporting_crime_police.description: Report a crime to police, describe what happened, provide details, understand police procedures, and get case information.
reporting_crime_police.setting: Police station or phone call to police

phases.name: Initial Report
phases.description: Report what happened and request help
essential_phrases: I need to report a crime
Where can I file a report?
phases.cultural_notes: Call emergency number (911 in US, 999 in UK, 112 in EU) for crimes in progress or immediate danger. Visit police station for non-emergency reports. Be clear and direct - police need facts to help. Stay calm even if upset. You have right to report any crime. Police must take reports seriously.
success_criteria: Communicate when and where it occurred

phases.name: Providing Details
phases.description: Give detailed information about incident
essential_phrases: On Main Street near the bank
The suspect was about 6 feet tall
He was wearing a black jacket
They drove away in a blue car
phases.cultural_notes: Be as specific as possible with descriptions: height, weight, age, hair, clothing, distinctive features. Note direction suspect went, vehicle description if any. List what was taken with serial numbers if available. Tell what you saw, not assumptions. Police will write report - verify accuracy before signing.

phases.name: Answering Questions
phases.description: Respond to officer's questions and clarify details
essential_phrases: I'm not sure about that detail
I can identify them if I see them again
I didn't get a clear look
learning_objectives: Admit when you don't know something
phases.cultural_notes: Only state what you actually saw or know - don't guess or embellish. 'I don't know' is acceptable answer. Police may ask same question multiple ways to verify details. Being uncertain about some details is normal and honest. You may be asked to give written statement or identify suspects from photos later.

phases.name: Next Steps and Case Number
phases.description: Understand what happens next and get case information
essential_phrases: Can I get a case number?
How long will the investigation take?
Who should I call for updates?
learning_objectives: Know who to contact for updates
phases.cultural_notes: Case/report number is essential for insurance claims and follow-up. Keep copy of police report - you may need to pay small fee for certified copy. Detective may be assigned for serious crimes. Not all crimes are solved - police prioritize based on evidence and seriousness. Victim services provide support and information. Follow up if you remember additional details.
success_criteria: Know how to get updates or provide more info

cultural_context.rights: You have right to report crimes and receive police assistance
cultural_context.language: Request interpreter if needed - police must provide
cultural_context.documentation: Keep case number and report copy for insurance/legal purposes

lost_documents_replacement.name: Dealing with Lost or Stolen Documents
lost_documents_replacement.description: Report lost/stolen passport, ID, or important documents, navigate bureaucracy, understand replacement process, and prevent identity theft.

phases.name: Reporting the Loss
phases.description: Report lost or stolen documents to authorities
essential_phrases: My wallet was stolen with my ID
I need to report missing documents
I don't know where I lost it
phases.cultural_notes: Report lost passport immediately to police and embassy/consulate. Police report often required for replacement. For stolen documents, report to prevent identity theft. Cancel credit cards immediately. Some countries allow online reporting. Time is critical - quick reporting prevents fraudulent use.
success_criteria: Understand why quick reporting is critical

phases.name: Embassy/Consulate Contact
phases.description: Contact embassy for passport replacement
essential_phrases: I need to replace my passport
Can I get an emergency passport?
phases.cultural_notes: Your country's embassy/consulate helps citizens abroad. Regular passport replacement takes 2-4 weeks. Emergency passports available if travel is urgent but limited validity. Bring police report, ID photos, proof of citizenship, and fee (usually $100-200). Some embassies have walk-in hours, others require appointments. Consulates in major cities provide same services.

phases.name: Replacement Documentation
phases.description: Learn requirements and gather necessary documents
essential_phrases: Can I get a birth certificate copy?
Where do I submit the application?
learning_objectives: Know where to obtain needed documents
phases.cultural_notes: Passport replacement requirements: application form, police report, 2 passport photos, proof of citizenship (birth certificate or previous passport), government ID if available, fee. Photos must meet specific requirements (size, background). Some documents may need to be notarized or certified. Keep copies of all documents submitted. Payment often by money order or credit card, not always cash.

phases.name: Prevention and Follow-up
phases.description: Understand fraud prevention and follow-up procedures
essential_phrases: How will I know when it's ready?
Should I worry about identity theft?
Can someone else pick it up?
phases.cultural_notes: Lost/stolen documents can be used for identity theft. Place fraud alert with credit bureaus. Monitor bank accounts for suspicious activity. Some countries notify database when passport reported lost - old one becomes invalid even if found. New passport will have different number. Most replacements ready in 2-6 weeks. Emergency documents take 1-3 days but limited validity. Pickup usually in person with ID.

cultural_context.embassy_services: Your embassy helps citizens abroad with lost documents
cultural_context.processing_time: Regular replacement takes weeks; emergency faster but limited
cultural_context.costs: Replacement fees typically $100-200 plus document costs
cultural_context.prevention: Carry copies of important documents separately when traveling

gym_membership_signup.name: Joining a Gym or Fitness Center
gym_membership_signup.description: Sign up for gym membership, take facility tour, understand equipment and classes, and learn gym etiquette.

phases.name: Membership Options
phases.description: Discuss membership plans and costs
essential_phrases: What membership options do you have?
phases.cultural_notes: Gyms have various plans: month-to-month (more expensive, no commitment), annual (cheaper, requires commitment), multi-year (best rate, long commitment). Initiation fees common. Read contract carefully - some hard to cancel. Ask about trial period or day passes first. January has signup promotions (New Year's resolutions). Can often negotiate better rates, especially if paying year upfront.

phases.name: Facility Tour
phases.description: Tour facility and learn about equipment and amenities
phases.cultural_notes: Modern gyms have cardio (treadmills, bikes, ellipticals), weights (machines and free weights), group fitness classes, locker rooms with showers. Some have pool, sauna, basketball court. Hours vary - 24-hour gyms common. Towels may be provided or bring your own. Lock valuables in locker. Peak hours 5-7 PM weekdays. Wear athletic shoes and appropriate clothing.

phases.name: Getting Started
phases.description: Set goals and learn how to begin
essential_phrases: Can someone show me the equipment?
What do you recommend for beginners?
Can I work with a trainer?
phases.cultural_notes: Most gyms offer free orientation for new members - take it! Staff shows how to use equipment safely. Personal trainers available (extra cost) for customized workout plans. Group classes good for motivation and instruction. Start slowly if new to exercise - injury prevention important. Gyms have staff who can answer questions. Don't be intimidated - everyone started as beginner.

phases.name: Policies and Etiquette
phases.description: Learn gym rules and proper etiquette
essential_phrases: Is there a time limit on machines?
phases.cultural_notes: Gym etiquette: wipe down equipment after use, share equipment during peak hours, return weights to rack, don't drop weights, limit phone use, wear deodorant, don't reserve equipment, respect personal space. Some gyms ban certain behaviors (grunting, taking photos, dropping weights). Guest policies vary. Proper shoes required. Clean gym clothes expected. Following etiquette makes gym pleasant for everyone.

cultural_context.peak_hours: 5-7 PM weekdays busiest; mornings and midday quieter
cultural_context.etiquette: Wiping equipment and sharing are universal expectations
cultural_context.personal_space: Gyms can feel intimidating but everyone welcome

concert_event_attendance.name: Attending a Concert or Live Show
concert_event_attendance.description: Purchase tickets, navigate venue, find seats, order concessions, and discuss the performance.
concert_event_attendance.setting: Concert hall, theater, or music venue

phases.name: Ticket Purchase
phases.description: Buy tickets for event
essential_phrases: Do you have tickets for tonight's show?
learning_objectives: Purchase tickets at box office or online
phases.cultural_notes: Buy tickets online (convenient, fees apply) or box office (no service fees). Seat prices vary by location - closer and center cost more. General admission is standing room, no assigned seats. Shows can sell out days or weeks in advance for popular acts. Scalpers sell tickets outside but illegal in some places and may be fraudulent. Print or mobile tickets usually both accepted.

phases.name: Venue Entry and Navigation
phases.description: Enter venue and find seats
essential_phrases: Can you help me find my seat?
phases.cultural_notes: Arrive 30-45 minutes early for parking, entry, and finding seats. Have tickets ready (printed or on phone). Ushers help find seats - tip them if seated personally (optional $1-2). Restrooms have long lines at intermission - go before show. Photography/video often prohibited. Turn off phone before show starts. Some venues have coat check.

phases.name: Ordering Concessions
phases.description: Order food and drinks at venue
essential_phrases: Can I pay with a card?
I'll have popcorn and a drink
phases.cultural_notes: Venue prices expensive (2-3x normal). Concession stands throughout venue. Long lines before show and at intermission. Some venues allow bringing water bottles. Alcoholic drinks at most concerts/shows (ID required, usually 18-21+ depending on country). Credit cards accepted but small purchases may require minimum. Tip bartenders $1-2 per drink.

phases.name: Discussing the Show
phases.description: Talk about the performance with others
phases.cultural_notes: Encore is additional performance after main set - show appreciation by clapping/cheering. Standing ovation for exceptional performances (audience stands and claps). No talking during quiet performances (classical, theater). Singing along okay at some concerts, not others - follow crowd. Sharing experience on social media common. Live music creates shared memories - discussing it enhances enjoyment.

cultural_context.timing: Arrive early; shows often start on time
cultural_context.etiquette: No talking during performance, phones off, standing ovation for exceptional shows
cultural_context.costs: Tickets vary widely; venue concessions expensive
cultural_context.experience: Live shows are social and cultural experiences to be shared

language_class_enrollment.name: Enrolling in a Language or Adult Education Class
language_class_enrollment.description: Inquire about classes, understand levels and schedules, register for course, and prepare for first day.
language_class_enrollment.setting: Language school or adult education center

phases.name: Class Inquiry
phases.description: Ask about available courses and programs
essential_phrases: What language courses do you offer?
phases.cultural_notes: Adult education widely available in community colleges, language schools, cultural centers. Classes often 6-12 weeks, meeting 1-3 times weekly. Morning, afternoon, evening, and weekend options accommodate work schedules. Summer intensive courses also available. Most programs use Common European Framework levels (A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, C2) or equivalent.

phases.name: Assessment and Placement
phases.description: Discuss current level and take placement test
essential_phrases: Do I need a placement test?
I studied Spanish in high school
How do you determine the level?
phases.cultural_notes: Placement tests help put you in right level for success. Tests usually written (grammar, vocabulary) and sometimes oral (speaking ability). Being placed lower than expected is okay - solid foundation important. Can move up if class too easy. Self-assessment often inaccurate. Starting in beginner class is fine - no shame in being a beginner.

phases.name: Registration and Payment
phases.description: Enroll in class and complete payment
phases.cultural_notes: Registration usually online or in person. Pay tuition (full course cost) plus registration fee. Textbooks extra cost ($30-100). Payment plans may be available. Deadlines for registration and payment - register early as classes fill up. Refund policies vary - full refund if dropped before class starts, partial if dropped in first week. Financial aid sometimes available for low-income students.

phases.name: First Day Preparation
phases.description: Understand expectations and prepare for first class
essential_phrases: How much time should I study?
What if I miss a class?
phases.cultural_notes: Attendance important - most classes allow few absences. Homework expected (1-2 hours per class session). Bring textbook, notebook, pen, dictionary to every class. Participate actively - language learning requires practice. Ask questions when confused. Study between classes essential for progress. Form study groups with classmates. Many teachers use email for assignments and announcements.
success_criteria: Know exact class location and time

cultural_context.lifelong_learning: Adult education valued and widely available
cultural_context.flexibility: Many schedule options accommodate working adults
cultural_context.assessment: Placement tests ensure appropriate level for success
cultural_context.participation: Active engagement expected in language classes

parent_teacher_conference.name: Attending a Parent-Teacher Conference
parent_teacher_conference.description: Meet with teacher to discuss child's progress, understand educational system, ask questions, and collaborate on child's success.

phases.name: Progress Overview
phases.description: Hear about child's academic and social progress
essential_phrases: How do they get along with others?
phases.cultural_notes: Parent-teacher conferences typically 15-30 minutes, scheduled 1-2 times per year. Teachers discuss academics, behavior, and social development. Bring questions and notepad. Both parents encouraged to attend. If non-native English speaker, request translator in advance. Teachers want to partner with parents for student success. Remain calm and open even if hearing concerns.

phases.name: Discussing Challenges
phases.description: Address concerns and understand issues
essential_phrases: Is this normal for their age?
phases.cultural_notes: Teachers have child's best interest at heart. Concerns about performance, behavior, or social skills should be taken seriously. Ask specific questions about what's observed. Share information about home situation if relevant (stress, changes, health issues). Work together rather than blaming. Some struggling is normal - early intervention helps prevent bigger problems.

phases.name: Creating Action Plan
phases.description: Develop strategies to support child's success
essential_phrases: What can we do at home?
phases.cultural_notes: Teachers often suggest specific strategies: reading 20 minutes nightly, math practice websites, homework routine, limiting screen time. Ask for resource recommendations. Many schools offer free tutoring, reading programs, counseling. Special education services available if needed (evaluation required). Set realistic goals and timeline. Consistency at home crucial for improvement. Stay in communication via email.
success_criteria: Know parent role in supporting child

phases.name: Questions and Follow-up
phases.description: Ask remaining questions and schedule follow-up
essential_phrases: Can I email you with questions?
What's the best way to reach you?
phases.cultural_notes: Teachers appreciate involved parents. Email is usually best for non-urgent questions. Response may take 24-48 hours. Schedule another conference if serious concerns. Most teachers send progress reports between conferences. Parent portal shows grades online. Open communication helps student success. Thank teacher for their work and time.

cultural_context.partnership: Teachers and parents work together for student success
cultural_context.frequency: Conferences 1-2 times yearly, more if concerns
cultural_context.resources: Schools offer tutoring, counseling, special education if needed
